name: Hrunting
symbolism:
Limits of Human Achievement
                
                    Hrunting's failure represents one of Beowulf's central themes: the limits of
                    human craft and martial prowess against supernatural evil. No matter how
                    excellent the weapon or how skilled the warrior, some foes require more than
                    mortal means to defeat.
                

                The Named Sword Tradition
                
                    In Germanic heroic literature, named swords carried their own identities and
                    reputations. Hrunting joins weapons like Naegling (Beowulf's own sword), Gram
                    (Sigurd's blade), and countless others that were treated as characters in their
                    own right. These swords accumulated history through their wielders' deeds.
                

                Redemption and Reconciliation
                
                    The loan of Hrunting marks Unferth's transformation from antagonist to supporter.
                    His willingness to part with his treasured weapon, and Beowulf's gracious
                    treatment of both man and sword, demonstrates themes of honor, generosity, and
                    reconciliation central to Anglo-Saxon heroic culture.
longDescription:
The Ancient Heirloom Blade - Beowulf's Borrowed Sword Hrunting is one of two named swords in the Old English epic poem Beowulf, lent
                    to the hero by Unferth, a Danish courtier who had initially questioned Beowulf's
                    heroic credentials. The sword is described as an ancient heirloom, a weapon of
                    proven worth that had never failed any warrior who carried it into battle -
                    until it encountered the supernatural protection of Grendel's mother.

extendedContent.content:
Hrunting is one of two named swords in the Old English epic poem Beowulf, lent
                    to the hero by Unferth, a Danish courtier who had initially questioned Beowulf's
                    heroic credentials. The sword is described as an ancient heirloom, a weapon of
                    proven worth that had never failed any warrior who carried it into battle -
                    until it encountered the supernatural protection of Grendel's mother.
                
                
                    The name "Hrunting" is of uncertain etymology, but may be related to Old English
                    words meaning "thrusting" or possibly connected to a proper name. Like other
                    named swords in Germanic heroic literature, Hrunting possessed its own identity
                    and reputation, accumulated through generations of martial service.
                
                
                    Hrunting's failure against Grendel's mother is one of the key moments in Beowulf,
                    demonstrating that even the most proven mortal weapons cannot always prevail
                    against supernatural evil. Only the giant-forged sword Beowulf finds in the
                    monster's lair can defeat her.
extendedContent.title: Description and Nature

extendedContent.content:
The Gift
                
                    After Beowulf's victory over Grendel, the monster's mother came to avenge her
                    son, killing one of King Hrothgar's closest companions. Beowulf volunteered to
                    pursue her to her underwater lair. Before he departed, Unferth - who had earlier
                    mocked Beowulf's swimming contest with Breca - offered him Hrunting.
                
                
                    This gesture marked a significant character moment for Unferth. By offering his
                    prized weapon, he acknowledged Beowulf's superiority and sought to contribute
                    to the hero's success. The poem notes that Unferth had forgotten his earlier
                    boasts, recognizing now that he himself lacked the courage to face the monster.
                

                The Failure
                
                    In the underwater hall of Grendel's mother, Hrunting failed for the first time
                    in its long history. Despite its proven edge and venerable reputation, the blade
                    could not bite into the monster's flesh. The poem suggests that some form of
                    supernatural protection rendered her invulnerable to mortal weapons.
extendedContent.title: Hrunting in Beowulf
